Posts.Content: Be patient my friend. Mine took about 60 days but the last 30 weren't bad at all. In fact by that time things were going well enough that I decided to try Levitra to get on with the rest of my recovery. I'm sure it was a total coincidence but from the day I took that first 20 mg Levitra forward I didn't require another pad. You will get there on your own schedule...but you will get there. PS...do your Kegels..they work

Posts.Title: Dribble, dribble

Posts.Content: First I want to say I've been a reader for years and have always been in awe of willingness to help ones fellow man I've seen here. Now I guess it's my turn to come forth asking for help. I have 2 questions. 1. As you can see I'm having a little PSA issue currently (it ain't really little to me...worrying the stew out of me). My Uro, who has reportedly done 3000 robotic prostatectomies, is very calm about my PSA fluctuations...I'm not. He says he has many patients in this same boat whose PSA is bouncing around but is not progressing. He has always been very confident that I probably wouldn't recur. I believe him but I also know that this is a very personal disease that is different in every man. For the record I talked to a radiation oncologist in Feb who at the time agreed to give more time to see if a trend develops (I have another appt with him next week). Have you guys had much experience with my type situation ? 2. As I just stated my uro/surgeon is a high volume guy who is very good at what he does. When I met with my RO I made the statement that I was also thinking about enlisting a medical oncologist since my surgeon's work was done. He informed me quickly that my uro/surgeon would also be the one who would administer any ADT etc if it was needed down the line. I love my surgeon and would have him do my surgery 100 out of 100 times but he now has so many patients I'm concerned I need another team member on my side to watch this thing closely. What say yall ?

Posts.Content: Prato, Feather and Michael , I just want you to know how much I appreciate your responses. I can't express what it means to have guys like you on my side. I'm trying a new lab this week and also making an appointment with a nationally known MO a few hours away. Again thank you for your advice and encouragement...it really means a lot to me.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman One other thought… How does a PSA go from .11 to undetectable in six months? Was it the same lab? I wonder if there was a lab error on the .11. On the other hand probably not because you had the .09 as well. That's a big drop. Thanks Pratoman and best of luck to you too. I was thinking the same thing about the big drop. The urology group my surgeon is with has it's own lab and although they are a top flight, high volume outfit I've wondered the same thing. Getting PSA test results in 45 mins however is nice if they are accurate. I've even wondered if some of my doctor's lack of concern comes from the fact he knows their lab has problems their test results are unreliable as hell anyway LOL. I think I'm going to let my RO submit a sample to another lab as he offered last time.

Posts.Content: I've read enough to say there seems to be a majority that agrees moderate exercise slightly increase testosterone levels particularly in those who have not been on an exercise plan . There also seems to be an overwhelming majority that agrees exercise should be an integral part of everyone's regiment to fight our common enemy PC. We all know testosterone feeds PC. To my question....can starting a moderate exercise program induce enough additional testosterone production to effect any residual cancer after treatment to the point it would cause a PSA "bounce" ?
